questions.question: Now, sorry for the romanticized question, but when did you first fall in love with programming?
Did you ever see the computer as like an extension of your mind, like something able to achieve?
I'll go to Brazil and Argentina, but will I truly understand the people if I don't understand the language?
Can I write programs that can be used by biomedical engineers, by all kinds of people that don't know programming?
And how do you connect the ethos of cooperative development with the necessity of creating profits?
And I saw that when I had a transition in a condo, when a new CEO came in, right?
Like, is there some key ideas that were just like sticking to you that this is the fundamental ideas?
So that's where NumPy came from, was my thinking, hey, I can do this, and who else is going to?
So as soon as I get that much money, or I said five years, right?
So I wonder if you can comment, is there like a difference between their implementations?
Do you wish that they were all using NumPy or like in this abstraction over GPU?
Do you really understand the notion of a hash map and how the dictionary is implemented?
Instead of the internals of GCC or the internals of the Intel compiler, like, how do I extend that?
And a neighboring design question is, do you also create a package manager that spans multiple programming languages?
How do I write NumPy code or NumPy Lite code if I want it to run across a cluster?
Do I slow down my spend on Google ads or my spend on Facebook ads?
One of the things that always works is to limit what you're trying to solve, right?
